reviews.review_title: Decent but not all you'd want in a Batman movie
reviews.content: BATMAN: MASK OF THE PHANTASM is a prime example of a good movie gone awry. The producers of "Batman: The Animated Series" wanted to bring their characters to the big screen, so they decided on a formula. They would 1. introduce a chilling new villain called The Phantasm, 2. have The Phantasm frame Batman for several murders, 3. delve into Batman's past, 4. get rid of Robin, 5. give Bruce Wayne a love interest, and 6. throw The Joker in for good measure. Sounds like a winner, doesn't it. Unfortuately, the movie comes up short on several levels. First, The Phantasm. For one thing, he's never actually called by that name in the entire movie. How is the audience supposed to know who "Phantasm" is? Imagine someone trying to write a summary of this movie: "Well, it stars Batman and The Joker and some guy with a skull mask and a cleaver for a hand." Other gripes about The Phantasm include that he seems too supernatural (a few clues are dropped here and there that Phantasm is using some weird chemical to make himself disappear like a ghost, but the movie never plays this up)and that he has an awesome cleaver on his hand and NEVER, EVER uses it through the entire movie. Instead, he kills his victims by more subtle, impersonal methods. What kind of psychotic slasher is he? Kevin Conroy, on the other hand, is excellent as the voice of Bruce Wayne/Batman. He's determined and moody, but not a freak like Keaton's Batman. He actually has some natural human qualities that the film accentuates very well. Then you have the villains. For the most part, they're dumb, stereotypical hoods who smoke cigarettes, have exaggerated mannerisms, and are all as intelligent as a crate full of rocks. The Joker (voiced by Mark Hamill) manages to put in a stellar performance, but he certainly can't bring the devilish nuances that Jack Nicholson gave to Joker. At times, Joker talks and acts like a four-year-old with Attention Deficit Disorder, and his manic Irishman accent really gets annoying by the end of the movie. Also, he isn't as clever as we'd believe him to be and is woefully unprepared to do battle with The Phantasm. He has no henchmen, just a couple of old-fashioned robots and some buzzing helicopters that are about as frightening as a litter of newborn kittens. Characterizations aside, the film is fun to look at and watch. Danny Elfman's score is used to good effect, as is many ideas used by Burton in the live-action films (especially the paradoxical settings that blend the 1940s with our modern era). The story is also top-notch, though it is bogged down by too many flashbacks. The finale is the best part, for it includes the unmasking of The Phantasm (who isn't quite what you'd expect "him" to be!). Will kids like this movie? Well, it isn't a Burton film. There's no scenes of people being electrocuted, burned alive, tossed off cathedrals, or having their noses bitten off by drooling subhumans. Still, the story gets a little too preachy (not to mention monotonous) at times, and there are many extremely scary scenes. The Phantasm's costume is one of the scariest ever seen on a Batman character, and we get to see two victims of Joker's Smylex toxin (one dead, the other lying in a hospital bed howling like a hyena). I'd recommend this film only to older children, adolescents, and adults. The movie isn't destined to be a classic like the Burton films, but it's quite good on its own. Even if you are not a fan of the television show, see this movie for a whole new spin on Batman.

reviews.review_title: Batman the way he is meant to be!
reviews.content: If there is a definitive Batman movie out there...this is it! I grew up watching Batman: The Animated Series and am an avid graphic novel collector. The plot of this film is by far one of the best ever submitted to the Batman mythology. Not to mention the exquisite animation and voice talents of Kevin Conroy and the great Mark Hamill. Not only is the acting in this film amazing, and the dialogue well-crafted, but the story is compelling and real. The group who made the original BTAS simply get the character and it shows in their work.To sum it all up: I wish I had more hands so I could give this movie FOUR THUMBS WAY UP! It is possibly the greatest Batman film of all time, and certainly tops my list.

reviews.review_title: Way better than the stupid cartoon.
reviews.content: Contains spoilersBatman returns to movie screens, but this time he's doing so in pen and paint form.  The feature has Bruce Wayne's alter ego being framed for grisly murders by another vigilante... this one called the Phantasm.  The Phantasm has targeted mob bosses around Gotham, and the mob has begun searching for the killer, including Batman's nemesis, the Joker, voiced brilliantly as usual by Mark Hamill.  Tying in with matters is Bruce encountering his lost love, Andrea, which causes him to reflect back on his events of his past with her, including his transformation into the guise of Batman.  This is a very good animated feature, featuring strong animation, a great soundtrack, and an excellent voice cast.  However, two of the reasons I enjoyed this film were things that the animated movie were able to get away with, things that Batman: The Animated Series, or Fox to be specific, wouldn't allow:1.  Characters die.  There was never any death in TAS.  Although this is also a good thing in ways, when one is discussing Batman, of all things, death is usually a common issue.  No death can be good to hide from the really little kids, but can also cause a series to become extremely unrealistic and laughable(Cough, G I Joe, cough).  Here, though, many of the mob bosses are killed by the Phantasm quite gruesomely, and the animated Joker is seen using his infamous, and quite lethal, Joker Venom effectively for the very first time.  The fights are also quite violent, unlike in the animated show, we actually get to see Batman bleed, something that surprised when I first saw the film back during its theatrical release.2.  Batman doesn't always win.  I'm sorry, but when I realized Batman: The Animated Series ALWAYS had Batman come out on top and save Gotham from whatever crime boss or sadistic villain he faced, I grew out of it and stopped watching.  Here, however, he is humbled greatly.  I actually compared this to an early episode of the TV series, "On Leather Wings," in which he is also framed and being chased by the police.  On the episode he avoided the cops and was able to get away from them quite easily.  Here, though, he had great difficulty trying to get away and almost wound up in police custody, even at one point being horribly wounded AND losing his mask.So this is at last the good animated version of Batman fans were looking for.  I suggest fans see this.  Don't worry, it's accessible, even if you've never seen an episode of Batman: The Animated Series before in your life. Oh, and an interesting tidbit: Dana Delany, the voice of Andrea, also went on to do the voice of Lois Lane in the animated versions of Superman and Justice League.

reviews.review_title: Joker is the best part of this.
reviews.content: Mark Hamill is one of the best Jokers (voices at least) of any I've seen. And I've seen and heard about all of them. That said the plot gets a little dry at one point but then gets new life when the Joker shows up. Such great antics. and I LOVE when he SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERTJoker gives the councilman smiles and he goes crazy. That's one of the best parts. All in all though this is one of the best animated films I've seen. If you are a fan of the Animated series or even a fan of the comics alone, check this out. Word of warning, it is really hard for kids to get some of the stuff. There are a lot of flashbacks. This is really more for adults or teens.

reviews.review_title: The Best Batman Movie there ever has been, and ever will be.
reviews.content: Batman is a complex creature, a temperamental stew. One wrong ingredient, one mistake, and the whole thing falls apart. Adam West was great at the time, but with age has become a joke. The 1989 version was critically acclaimed for being dark and moody, but failed to have a convincing love story, and was pretty much entirely about it's villain.Batman: Mask of the Phantasm fixes that. Andrea Beaumont is not only a complex character in her own right (instead of a one-note love interest) but her romance with Bruce is also convincing, powerful and something the audience wants to see.While the Joker is in it, and he does indeed steal the show. Batman's and Andrea's trials and issues don't pale in comparison. He manages to fit himself into the plot and instead of forcing Batman into simply beating up the bad guy and saving the day, he helps move along the plot and wrap up everything that's going on.The plot itself is captivating. With twists and turns that while, not entirely unpredictable, manage to create a sense of mystery and intrigue for the viewer. While the movie is told partially in flashbacks, they're necessary to reveal the motivations of the various characters.The Cast sells it brilliantly. Hamill's Joker makes you fear him, and yet laugh with him at the same time. Conroy's Batman is sympathetic and interesting to watch, as with every action he drives another nail into his proverbial coffin. Delany's Beaumont is sexy, quirky, and brainy. While Zimbalist Jr.'s Alfred provides a bit of needed comedy relief and emotional support for Bruce (I admit it, his speech to him at the end of the movie almost brings me to tears every time.) Hart Bochner rounds out the cast as the slimy and sniveling Arthur Reeves.All in all, a gallivanting triumph. Showing the tragedy of Batman alongside a tragic and captivating love story. And who knew there was going to be a joker in the deck? You think by now they'd be expecting it.

reviews.review_title: Top drawer animated superhero film
reviews.content: Following on from the first series of Batman: The Animated Series, Mask of the Phantasm features the same art style and most of the cast reprise their roles as well. In many ways this feels like and extended episode of the Series, with no real enhancements in the audio/visual department to step it up, but since the animated series was excellent anyway, it's no big deal. The plot concerns itself with Batman being mistaken for a vigilante killer who is taking out Gotham's mob bosses one by one. The story is engaging, if a bit cliche... and the voice work and atmosphere are all very good. If you're a fan of the 90's animated series (and lets face it, who isn't) this is a must see.

reviews.review_title: The most accurate portrayal of Batman on film, ever.
reviews.content: The film maintains the "dark deco" direction and style of Batman: The Animated Series under the direction of Eric Radomski and Bruce W. Timm and the writing of Alan Burnett and Paul Dini (all of whom worked on TAS), and features the same voices talents as the show, including Kevin Conroy as Batman/Bruce Wayne, Efrem Zimbalist Jr as Alfred, Bob Hastings as Commissioner Gordon, Robert Constanzo as Detective Harvey Bullock, and Mark Hamill as The Joker. Basically, the movie takes all the best elements of the series, and puts it together as a longer episode. Except that if it were an episode, it never would have made it past the censors. Also, it'd be the best episode in the history of the show.As a theatrically-released movie with a 76 minute running time, Mask of the Phantasm had license to do things the Saturday afternoon cartoon show could not do. It's a darker, more mature look at Batman than the series could be, receiving a PG rating. It's no Sin City or Heavy Metal, but is more intense than usual, showing murder, blood, and allusions to sex that could never be shown on the show. Which is not to say that it's an adult film, because it's not. It's still an animated movie about a super-hero, and is still primarily for kids (albeit, older kids). It just means that Mask of the Phantasm is closer to the comic book than the series is allowed to be.In terms of story, Mask of the Phantasm is a mystery movie, as a new vigilante, who bears similarities to Batman, comes to Gotham and begins executing mob bosses. Batman must figure out who this new vigilante is to end the Phantasm's rampage, while Batman himself is being accused of the crimes. Meanwhile, a former love is back in Gotham (voiced by Dana Delany), drudging up painful memories for Bruce Wayne of the one who got away. While dealing with the Phantasm, his long-lost love, and Gotham Police, Batman also has to deal with The Joker, who is somehow involved in everything.The movie is an excellent combination of action and suspense, and until the recent release of Batman Begins, was easily the best Batman film ever (but it now must place second). Strangely, since it is a cartoon, this film has the most convincing and realistic love story in Batman movie history (although, to be fair, there's no real competition in that area, as all the other love stories in Batman movies have been rushed and unconvincing). Comic book fans will geek out over the Year One like flashbacks featuring a non-costumed young Bruce Wayne attempting to fight crime, and the appearance of the Phantasm, who, with a cape, spectre-like mask, and scythe, bears a strong resemblance to Year Two's murderous vigilante The Reaper.Personally, I absolutely loved this movie. However, it's not a movie for everyone. If you're not already a fan of Batman or Batman: The Animated Series, then I don't think this movie would have much of interest for you. But if you are a fan of the series or the character, then I highly recommend you check this film out.

reviews.review_title: best of the batman films
reviews.content: If you like the cartoon you'll like this movie.  And I'm talking about the older Batman cartoons, not the newer dumbed-down version.  Kevin Conroy has the coolest voice on TV, and Mark Hamill gives a terrific no-holds-barred performance as the Joker.  The problem with the Batman 1-4 movie series is that they try to combine action, romance, and Batman's feelings of angst, and in the end succeed at doing none of them.  The animated movie (correctly) focuses on Batman's pain.  Because of this, it's not really a kid's movie.  Instead of choosing to animate in sort of a literal way, the show is animated in a stylized way a la Tarzan.  This is how animation should be done - if you're going to animate something it should not be because you're aiming it at kids, but rather because you can portray something in a way that's not possible with live action. The dark city and blocky animation suggest loneliness and desolation, and look at the way in which the eyes of the Joker and Batman move and squint.  I especially liked the Andrea/Batman parallel - we discover they have the same formative experience, and ultimately suffer the same ending fate.  My only gripe is that I pretty much knew who the (other) bad guy was about 1/2 way through. Still, this movie is one of my favorites.

reviews.review_title: Best Batman yet
reviews.content: This is the best Batman to be seen on the big screen.  Far better than any of the previous live action films, Mask of the Phantasm captures the moodiness, the angst, and the pathos of the Batman comics.  Here we see Bruce Wayne as the dedicated but torn and tormented soul he is.  Here also, we finally see Batman fighting crime in all his proper glory: flying from the rooftops, crashing through windows, kicking serious booty and demonstrating that he is the most amazing "normal" human on the planet. This movie presents Batman as he was meant to be.(And as an additional bonus, the mania of Hamill's Joker buries Nicholson's attempt.)

reviews.review_title: the true Dark Knight
reviews.content: For many Bat fans, BATMAN: MASK OF THE PHANTASM is the best interpretation of the character in any form, remaining more true to its source than even the original Tim Burton film did. The animation is about the same as the animated series this was spun off from, but the voice acting by Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, Dana Delaney, Efrem Zimbalist Jr., Hart Bochner, and others is top-notch. The multiple flashbacks sometime get to be a little too much, but they help to give us insight into Bruce Wayne's relationship with Andrea Beaumont and how she almost prevented him from becoming Batman. A failure in the theaters, it has since developed a loyal following of fans. This is a must-see for any Batman fan.

reviews.review_title: Phenomenal!
reviews.content: This animated movie shows why Batman The Animated Series is the greatest representation of any superhero of all time.

reviews.review_title: Little Phantasm, too much Batman Love, not enough Joker
reviews.content: Batman: Mask of the Phantasm focuses on a Batman love story with way too many flashbacks, a surprise and the Joker. Without giving away spoilers, the Phantasm is not actually that important and only shown sparsely in the animated film. I'd rather watch the TV series than this movie again. A majority is filled with flashbacks and Batman being confused how he should move forward with love. The highlights are the scenes with Mark Hammill doing an absolute fantastic job voicing The Joker as usual.

reviews.review_title: The Best Batman Portrayel
reviews.content: Batman mask of the phantasm is truly one of the best batman's films around, the darkness and extremely fascinating plot brings batman alive. The voices of joker by Mark Hamill is genius, and in my point of view a true batman film can only be perfect if it is animated, as all the best batman portrayals have been batman:Ats and batman beyond return of the joker. The film has a very interesting plot, with Batman being chased by the police for a crime he didn't commit, to the flashback of batman's past, showing how he became batman - similar to batman begins, to Bruce Wayne love life, Batman Mask of the Phantasm is the perfect Batman film.

reviews.review_title: I can see why Batman fans love this movie.
reviews.content: Before watching this, I foolishly didn't realize that this took place within the universe of the animated series. So I did not rewatch that show in preparation. But as a kid I watched it, and I rewatched it when it came to Netflix in my teenage years. So I had a vague familiarity with the show. And I don't really think it is a prerequisite that you watch the show before this movie.Having said all of that, it is very much a product of that climate. The animated series was launched off the back of Tim Burton proving that the character was both popular and highly profitable. From what I remember, and the praise from fans, the show is really good and possibly better than Burton's movies. And this movie follows in line with that reputation.It does much better character work than Burton's films (and I'm not sure if the whole series does the same), and the romance is far better than anything in his two films. The response to trauma from Andrea and Bruce and how they mirror each other and the effect that it all has on Bruce is so incredibly well done. We get to explore more of why somebody would run around in a bat suit all night. We see how he could have gone down a darker path, and how his path to salvation was cut off because of Gotham.Where this film excels in its characters, it unfortunately falls flat for me with its commentary. I was once a huge fan of Batman the character and I am sure that I would have loved this at that point in my life but unfortunately I grew out of that phase. I much more appreciate what Batman means as a symbol and how it fits in the larger metaphor of Gotham City. Stories about individuals often bore me because hero worship doesn't help anything. And maybe neither does Batman.Really good story about the tragedy of Bruce Wayne.

reviews.review_title: A film about Bruce Wayne
reviews.content:
"Vengeance blackens the soul, Bruce. I've always feared that you would become that which you fought against. You walk the edge of that abyss every night, but you haven't fallen in, and I thank heaven for that."
-AlfredMask of the Phantasm explores the broken yet simple at-heart character of Bruce Wayne. He longs for love just like an ordinary adult of his age would. It's this simple need of his that conflicts with the idealism of his alter ego. Because Batman cannot dwell on the paths of love, that's too much of a risk.Now imagine a kid who's endured so much pain falls for a girl who's had her share of trauma. The film revolves around the apocalyptic relationship of Bruce and Andrea Beaumont.As several mysteries unfold in the noir setting of a dark, rainy city (with an amazing soundtrack to back that up), Bruce is found fighting both the crimes in Gotham and the Batman.

reviews.review_title: Better than the live action films
reviews.content: Batman mask of the phantasm is really cool on many levels,the voices bring the characters to life (especially Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil. this is a must see classic

reviews.review_title: Absolutely Breathtaking (May Contain Spoilers)
reviews.content: I have seen this movie probably 100s of times and I love it. It is by far the best Batman movie ever. Even better than the live-action Tim Burton/Joel Schumacher films. It is absolutely breathtaking.Some of my favorite aspects of this movie were:-Andrea's passions: Bruce Wayne and the revenge for her father's death.-The Joker (Who doesn't love this clown?)-The Phantasm and the Joker's fight at the very end.-The very last scene when Andrea vanishes and is on the cruise ship.-The music of the movie (especially "I Never Even Told You")-The darkness of the movie-How it doesn't restrain itself to a normal animated movie.-Basically everything else, but these were special.I recommend this movie to anybody and everybody who like the 1992 Batman Animated Series, and the fans of the live-action Tim Burton/Joel Schumacher films.

reviews.review_title: Perhaps the finest portrayal of the Dark Knight on the silver screen
reviews.content: Batman: Mask of the Phantasm is a terrific adaptation of the hit Batman: The Animated Series, and truly serves to show reverence to this six decades-old character.  With a tight story, good dialogue, and plenty of exciting action sequences, this film is highly enjoyable for kids and adults alike.  The sequences portraying violence and minor bloodshed can be surprising, but in no way take away from the overall family-type quality of the film.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Batman films ever made
reviews.content: Great film, great story with a genuine twist, great ending, excellent Batman film, one of the best Batman films of all time.8.5/10

reviews.review_title: Rewards a Viewing, but Doesn't Match the Level Achieved by the Best Episodes
reviews.content: BATMAN: MASK OF THE PHANTASM (B-) is an animated Batman film that doesn't follow the live action Batman or Batman Returns but rather the animated cartoon series that came out in 1992 and featured an art deco 1930's Gotham. I was a big fan of the cartoon series - much more than the Burton films - and I think his film holds up fairly well against them. The central plot here is Batman's investigation into a series of murders of prominent gangsters. The cops begin to think Batman is behind them, but we discover that the mysterious Phantasm is behind. Can Batman figure out the mysterious connection between the murders before he is taken down by the policeman or another mysterious villain who appears in the final act. The thematic question of this fairly serious Batman story is whether or not Batman can move on and be happy by hanging up the cape and marrying Andrea Beaumont. Andrea Beaumont is the daughter of a missing finance man who has some connection to the gangster murders taking place. There's some nice sequences here and the story/action is enjoyable enough. This justifies a viewing from Batman fans, but doesn't quite equal the level some of the best episodes in the series achieved.

reviews.review_title: A lot better than I expected!
reviews.content: I stumbled onto Mask of the Phantasm a lot later than most Batman fans, so I must admit, I was pleasantly surprised to say the least when the end credits were rolling.  I actually--no, I REALLY--enjoyed it.  Given the Batman track record at the box office I was expecting and somewhat hit-and-miss affair. But wow, this movie really kept me on the edge of my seat.  Finding out about Bruce's earlier years was really cool.  And I was not expecting the villain to be who it turned out to be.  I would strongly recommend this film to any older Batman fan who had given up after Batman & Robin.  Ever since I have seen the movie I have tried to catch up on the animated series.Also don't hesitate to check out the Batman Beyond Movie.  It's pretty good, too.

reviews.review_title: Burtonesque
reviews.content:
A lot of people say that "Mask of the Phantasm" say it's better than the Burton films. What they fail to realize is that the animated series is based on Tim Burton's vision -- especially the Oscar-winning set and art design, now referred to as "dark deco". That said, "Mask of the Phantasm" is an excellent portrayal of the Dark Knight, which implies that perhaps being Batman wasn't exactly the best choice in Bruce Wayne's life. Being Batman seems to be a trap for Bruce -- he started it and there is no way to stop -- Bruce is too noble to stop, yet realizes that being Batman is a drain on his life.It also depicts Bruce as approaching middle-aged as well -- he's not young, and he knows that his years of crusading has robbed him of his better days.
The "Future" references are constant in the film -- keep an eye out for them.

reviews.review_title: Best superhero film ever
reviews.content: The story, the style, the music...everything makes this animated film the best superhero movie ever done. The series was a blast, but this film delivers better the goods. It's an adult and serious film, and by that I don't mean not suitable for children, but that it deals with adult themes such as responsability, wrath, love....what a good film should do. I always felt that the live action Batman films lacked many things, and this film proves it. The origin of the Batman, ala Year One, it's a joy to watch. Kudos for Bruce Timm and everyone involved!

reviews.review_title: This is probably the best Batman movie ever made.
reviews.content: The legacy of the Dark Knight continues through this animated masterpiece. With this being the best, most true-to-the-character adaptation of Batman for the big screen.  Animated or not, this is probably the best Batman movie ever made, it's what the live action films should be.  It's not campy like the Joel Schumacher adaptations.  This film is much darker and goes deeper into the world of Batman, the way Batman was originally envisioned.  You are automatically drawn in from the start with the epic soundtrack composed by Shirley Walker, which sets the tone perfectly for the film.  If you are a fan of Batman, this is the must have movie.

reviews.review_title: Hands down the best Batman movie, and it only rivals "Spiderman" as the best superhero movie.
reviews.content: It's very sad that this film was overlooked and ignored. Although I do find guilty pleasure in the live action Batman films, this is by far out does them all.The plot is intelligent and full of twists and turns, flawlessly combining the mob mystery with the love story it effects. All of the characters are very well developed, relatable (well the ones that intend to be), and entertaining. Even the score is awesome.The voice acting is perfect. Kevin Conroy is THE only voice who should play Batman. And Mark Hamill is the best Joker ever. period.This film stays so true to the original characters of the comic book that it is the only rival I would put against Spiderman (2002) as the best comic-to-film adaptation to date.My only complaint is that the animation in this film really isn't a step up from the TV show that spawned it's style. I LOVE the simplistic, geometric looking style that Warner Bros. gave this adaptation of Batman, I just wish a little more care was taken with it.Anybody who is remotely a fan of Batman, or the animated TV show, should see this great movie.

reviews.review_title: The perfect animated superhero film
reviews.content: This movie is filled with everything a great movie needs. Humor, action, drama, suspense, so on and so forth. Had this been a live action film it would have received so many Oscars.

reviews.review_title: The best batman film to be made
reviews.content: To me this is the best batman film to be made this film was made for the fans of the series but even if you haven't watched the series you will still enjoy the film because of its great story telling, great music score but what makes the film for me was the voice acting its excellent the performances that stick out are Kevin Conroy who plays batman and mark Hamil that plays the joker, mark Hamil should of won an a Oscar for that performance. overall this is one of the best animated films ever made its better than all the batman films old and new if your your a batman fan watch this film even if your not a batman fan still watch this film you will enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Best of the Batmen
reviews.content: Mask of the Phantasm is the best Batman movie yet.  The Adam West Batman is fun as pure camp; the 1990s Bat movies are hollow spectacles.  This animated Batman has more soul and depth than any of the live action adaptations. The animation is decent and looks like what people of the 1940s imagined their future would be.  This must be Batman as Bob Kane intended him.

reviews.review_title: Should Have Been Converted Into a Live Action Movie
reviews.content: Batman: Mask of The Phantasm Is one of the best Animated movie in existence. The Use of character revaluations, pathetic falacy, and symbols all make this one unique film that SHOULD be made into a live action movie. The character development of batman really shows his past in great detail, with him starting out to e a hero, and from his potential marriage top Andrea Beaumont. Also, the raw emotions that are trapped within Andrea develop her character with all of the hate, and anger inside her that make her, for the lack of a better term, "Go To The Darkside" of crime Fighting, where Batman has almost gone several times. Finally, the look into the Jokers past as a two bit hit-man 'climbing the ropes' of the mafia syndicate really show how inhumane he is behind all of the make-up

reviews.review_title: The Darkest movie of the Dark Knight
reviews.content: First of all, Batman: Mask of the Phantasm based on Batman's animated series. It, more than any batman animation I've seen goes deeply into batman's/Bruce's personal life. The story, which is split almost evenly between present day and flashbacks via Bruce's memories, is incredibly well written and gives more depth to its characters. It is also a Tragic love story of batman's love life. So, If you are looking for just a cute romantic movie I cannot recommend this one. It's wonderfully animated, very violent, and very slick. Easily the best Batman films.As a true Batman fan, I highly recommend this movie for every Batman fan.

reviews.review_title: Best at Bat/Animated Division!!
reviews.content: It would take the WB animation department to bring the best Batman movie to the screen.  I braved sub-zero temperature to see this film and I wasn't disappointed.  The romantic relationship was handled with a great deal of maturity as was the action sequences (was that actually blood I saw on Batman's face as he ran from the police).  We actually get to see someone die from the Joker's venom, rictus grin and all.  The final battle between Batman/Phantasm/Joker is a real standout.  I even liked that final song at end (sung by Tia Carrere, no less).

reviews.review_title: The Best Batman Movie Of The Twentieth Century
reviews.content: An absolute masterpiece composed by Warner Bros. No other Batman movies can live up to its standard (except Batman Begins), and as of yet, I've never seen a better animated movie.The script is brilliant, the story is their own improvisation and succeeds to be excellent in every aspect. The voice acting, I thought, was overwhelming compared to other cartoons. Kevin Conroy is the perfect voice for Batman. Gruff and petrifying. Mark Hammill is also a brilliant Joker. This has been given less credit than it deserves, and it deserves a lot of credit.Of course, a Batman film would not be without a few twisted villains. The Joker is the main villain, but does not actually have any plans for criminality until he is confronted by one of his former victims. The climatic ending is overwhelming, with Batman and the Joker absolutely battering the living hell out of each other. It doesn't hesitate to show blood or violence, and to a higher extent, it gives the film one of its dark elements.Bruce Wayne's former fiancée, Andrea has come back to Gotham City for a vengeance on all the mobsters who were involved in the killing of her father. Batman cannot allow that, it's his City. The joker is dragged into the frame when it is found he is one of the mobsters who was involved in the murder of her father. The story contains no flaws. None, whatsoever.The film possesses everything you'd hope for. A kick-ass Batman, violence, dark elements, a sense of romance, action, a good cast and a license of its own to be creative in its own story. The worst bit is the credits, when it finishes you off with a jazz-like song. That's the only thing I can say that's bad about it.A true landmark in movie history.

reviews.review_title: The Best Batman Ever
reviews.content: Note to the directors of all new Batman movies: sit down and watch this movie over and over again so you can see how Batman is SUPPOSED to be done.This movie has it all: an intriguing plot, interesting dialogue, rapid-fire action and good characterization.  It also shows you can have two costumed villains in the movie and still have the whole story center around BATMAN (take note, future directors: it all goes back to a GOOD STORY that doesn't assume the audience has the intelligence and attention span of a six-year-old hopped up on sugar and caffeine.)Whenever someone asks me what my favorite Batman movie is (which doesn't happen a whole lot, I admit), this is the one I name.  To date, it has never been surpassed, which is a bit of shame when you consider the resources the live-action Batman films have.  This is a gem, folks, run right out and rent it or buy it ASAP!

reviews.review_title: true batman story
reviews.content: By far, one of the best Batman movies ever. A true detective story that respects the characters and one of those rare cases in which a comic film respects and embellishes established comic continuity. This movie touches upon the humanity of the character of Batman. It shows that one of the greatest super heroes ever is not a single-minded revenge machine. Instead this film shows the man that is batman. He loves, he laughs, he smiles, he hurts, he grieves, he's finally depicted as being human. The action is fair and balanced, this film opted to show Batman doing some good 'ol fashioned detective work instead of driving the bat-mobile up walls or clashing with scene chewing villains. The story is a classic who-done-it? mystery, it employs the use of flashbacks, which is often a cheesy plot device but they're done right and they interlace perfectly with the story and push it forward. The plot involves the murdering of many mob bosses, and the authorities pin the murders on Batman. Batman has to evade authorities and find out who is really doing the killings.

reviews.review_title: Kitchen knife or stick of baloney? BALONEY!
reviews.content: Western animation has so much damn potential, why isn't it being realised? Batman: Mask of the Phantasm is in my opinion the best Batman flick ever made. There have been some shockers over the years, and I seem to be the only one who's not drooling over Batman Begins. Batman Begins was decent, but it's lacking something which this flick (and the series) have in stinking abundance: Style. The Batman animated series is so freaking classy; I just love it. The city is done perfectly; it is GOTHam after all, not New York. I totally dig the dark, gritty scenery, and the nighttime rain showers provide a haunting atmosphere. There is something that this series/film does which is hard to explain: they make Gotham believable, they make it seem real, and the flashbacks feel like history; not just character development. Little touches like the glimpses of characters in their younger lives add to this realism. I loved the scene with Bullock as a uniformed cop, and Joker as a sleazy criminal henchman; neither were overdone nor particularly over-dramatic. The development of batman was perfect too, not over the top at all. The directors/writers don't appear to feel the need to explain every little detail. Unlike a lot of blockbusters, they don't seem to be catering for the usual vegetables that need to be spoon fed. Maybe my cheese has slid off my cracker, but this seems like a intelligent filmThe reason I didn't give this 10: I took a star off because the Phantasm character was a teenie bit lame; the smoke disappearing act was pretty cheesy, along with a few other things about the character. reviews.review_title: An absolute thrill to see for the first time as a longtime fan of the series.
reviews.content: I have loved "Batman: The Animated Series" for the duration of my entire time on this Earth. Heck, I love Batman largely because of it. My favorite movie period is Christopher Nolan's "The Dark Knight", and I love that whole trilogy. Tim Burton's "Batman" and "Batman Returns" (which I like even more) are also incredible. I recently acquired the complete Batman animated series on Blu-ray and included with it were "Batman & Mr. Freeze: SubZero" (which was alright) and this film. I was very impressed with this movie. It's actually kind of a prequel/origin story for Batman in some ways. Guess you could say a "Batman Begins" that you can show to kids if you're not ready for them to see that one. That's not to imply that it is lesser than on it's own merits because it isn't as dark. I want to acknowledge the technical stuff first. It's not that surprising to me that the movie is beautifully animated, because the show is beautifully animated. It is praiseworthy though. I miss animation like this so much. But what impressed me more and what's been impressing me about the show also as I've been watching it recently is the sound mixing. The sound mixing is insane in this. Hearing the explosions, and punches, and the whooshing of the Batplane was a real joy. The same of course can be said of the musical score. Beautiful. The voice acting is really strong here too. The writing in this movie also is very good. The Phantasm and the motivations of this villain threw a curveball at me, and were surprisingly simpler than I thought they'd be. I wouldn't mind seeing a live-action interpretation of the character but changes would need to be made to conceal their identity. Or maybe not. It could still work. There were more characters in this movie than I was expecting also, and they fill the running time quite nicely without seeming to take more time away than necessary from Bruce/Batman. It's consistent in the way that it helps Gotham City feel like a real lived-in world, especially as it pertains to all of the lowlife criminals. And although I said it's kind of like a more appropriate "Batman Begins" for kids I still was surprised at the mature tone of it. But again, I don't know why. The series has always done that so well. This is wonderful. I was born in 1992 so I didn't see it in theaters for obvious reasons and I would have been a nuisance to everyone who did. It almost went straight to video but Warner Brothers made a last-minute decision to release it in theaters. It underperformed because of that last-minute decision, but in terms of quality, I'd say that they should have had a theatrical release in mind from the very beginning. One last thing : I'd recommend probably watching this first before you start watching the series given that it's a bit of an origin story and a prequel in some respects. But seeing it in any way certainly will add to your love of the show, because I'm just now seeing it as an adult who was born the same year that the show debuted. And I couldn't be happier that I did.

reviews.review_title: The "real" Batman Begins
reviews.content: Batman: The Animated Series was a Saturday morning cartoon series that aired on FOX Kids. I consider that particular series the best adaptation of Batman. The series did an amazing job of providing origins for many of Batman's famous villains. However, it never provided one for the title character. So, this is the team's way of creating a back story for their main character.When Bob Kane and Bill Finger created Batman back in 1939 they didn't feature an origin on the first issue. That was something they later dealt with and it wasn't even a full issue. It was just prologue for one of the stories. Bruce W. Timm and the rest of the gang remained true to that concept and don't exactly make this film into an origin tale. The origin is just back story for the actual plot. The plot is that a new vigilante has arrived into Gotham killing many mob bosses. Somehow Batman is confused for this new vigilante and he has to prove his innocence, while battling the Joker and catching up with an old girlfriend.Like the animated series this film is an amazing accomplishment. It's probably even better than Batman Begins. Too bad people don't see it because it's a cartoon.RATING: 4 (****) out of (****)

reviews.review_title: The only person in this room, controlled by his parents is you.
reviews.content: After looking at all these reviews, I'm sure that what I'm about to say is pretty redundant.  I'll say it anyway.This is film is, by far, the most accurate and most brilliant adaptation of the dark knight.  No other presentation of the Bat has captured it's true essence as this one has (including the 1989 film by Tim Burton).The film starts of with Batman breaking up a  counterfeit-money plot by the mob and immediately goes right into the meat of the story.  Gangsters are getting rubbed-out left and right.  The eye-witnesses are claiming to see hooded and caped figure at these crime scenes, which makes Batman the prime suspect.  If this isn't enough, a corrupt city councilman fronts his new re-election platform for eliminate the Bat ,for these murders ,at any cost. The timing couldn't be worse for the woman, who broke Bruces' heart ,to come back into town during all this. So Bruce has got his hands full will catching a killer, clearing his name and sorting out his feelings for his long-lost love.  This film out-does anything attempted in the tradition of Batman. 1. This film does what too may films failed or forgot to do, and that is actually focus the story on Batman.  The previous films gave too much attention on the corny and semi-campy villains.  Even the first Batman, as entertaining as it was , gave too much screen time to the Joker, and only skimmed the surface of who is Batman.  We learn more about the beginnings of Bruce Wayne, to understand his motives a little more intimately, from flash backs and events.  Kevin Conroys' voicing of Batman is so good, you'd wish he was casted in the live-action versions.2. This film keeps the situation down to earth with a simple murder mystery. No stupid large scale plots to poison people with smilax, steal the first born sons, brainwash with a stupid glow-box or freeze Gotham. This basic and non-childish premise was the basis for some potent suspense that challenged films like "Die-Hard" and "The Fugitive" The big chase between Batman and the swat-team had me on the edge of my seat chewing my nails to the bone.3. This film was not dumb it down for kids, (which the live-action films tend to do)  The story was serious and involving.  The dialogue and relationships were genuine.  Some of the more memorable scenes include this first prelude between Batman and Andrea Beaumont (Bruces' Ex) Another scene in the conversation between Bruce and Alfred.  As a matter of fact this film displays the best relationship with Bruce and Alfred.  "You think you know everything about me ,don't you" "I diapered you bottom.  I bloody well oht to, SIR!"Some viewers will criticize the animation quality of this film,  but I feel was original and appropriate for the needs of this film.  The musical score may be a little reminiscent on the old Danny Elfman themes, but since it was done by his original orcastrator, Sherley Walker, no harm, no foul.  Her score also lives up to the true Batman style.  The problems with this film, for starters, is that that it is too short. True ,for only 77mins, it seems to utilizes it's time well, but it should have been a bit longer to tie up the loose ends left behind.  We never find out if Batman ever gets to clear his name of the murders, or even how he is cleared. The big showdown with the Phantasm left the audience a little bit cheated, but the face off with the Joker compensated.  Yes the Joker is in this film  to and he is done very well by Mark Hamill.  Not to worry, this film is not short on surprises, so I won't blow any.  And if any reviews have, shame on you!!!Some may say that the ending left them hanging, but I believe that the very end of this film captured the true spirit of what Batman is all about.To sum up, no film has ever given the fans a better or more accurate depiction of the Batman legend as superbly and masterfully as this one.  It is the finest and most under-rated film in the last 50 years

reviews.review_title: Vengeance blackens the soul...
reviews.content: Everything else has already been said here. This is truly the best Batman movie. It puts even Tim Burton to shame. Now I enjoyed Batman + Batman Returns and I consider them fine additions to the Batman franchise, but they didn't focus on the title character as much as they should have. Phantasm patches things up where the live action films went wrong. Here we have Batman seen as the brooding avenger that he really is and we are given better insights as to why he became what he is. His parents don't just die and he decides to be a superhero. The conflict is much deeper than that and well done here. You actually got to know Bruce Wayne, as well as the Batman. Kevin Conroy is the best Batman, bar none. Keaton was good and West was fun, but Conroy simply rocks.Besides being true to the Batman mythos, it is a great film for other reasons. The score in this movie ties with Danny Elfman's and the Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker score for best score in a Batman film. The use of the choir in the movie was excellent. It was like the voices were speaking to Batman, haunting him and yet urging him on. It reminds me so much of the Crow (and that's always a good thing).The action in the movie is far from the cartoonish crap that's screwed up the last two Batflicks. We actually get the feeling that Batman may not make it out of here alive. The emotion in this movie is real and not the least bit wooden. The backstory drives at effective parallel to what's happening in the present story. Mark Hamill makes a great Joker (way better than Nicholson who took up too much screentime).There's nothing really left me to say except go see this movie. The animation may not be top notch, but the story and feeling is very much there. I can't praise it enough...

reviews.review_title: The second best Batman movie
reviews.content: Batman mask of the phantasm for a long time was my favourite Batman movie. One of two theatrically released animated Batman films. This and the Lego Batman Movie. But this movie is phenomenal. The movie tackle's themes of destiny, revenge, love and promises. Mask of the phantasm delves into why Batman is Batman. How he made a promise to his parents, to not allow this to happen to anyone else. However, Batman meets a girl named Andrea. She makes Batman reconsider his promise and his plan. To have a normal life because he never considered that he could possibly ever be happy. Just like any tragedy, that opportunity is stripped away, and he is forced to becomes the batman. To prowl the city, stopping the criminal element from creating another Bruce Wayne. Batman is almost destined to go down this path. At the end of the movie, Batman is faced with the same dilemma, stay Batman, or live a normal life, but again, it is taken away from him and ends the movie where he started, nearly alone, forcing himself on his one-man crusade. The story however is about this mysterious phantasm figure coming to Gotham and picking off members from a gang, but, from afar, the phantasm looks like Batman, so all these killings are framed on Batman, turning the police and the public on Batman. Batman needs to solve these mystery's and stop the phantasm and prove his innocents. The flashbacks and origins are interwoven into the narrative, creating impact and adds to the film while also not overstaying it's welcome as the shortest Batman movie of all time, but the movie says all it needs to say in that time frame, not overstaying it's welcome. This movie is what Batman forever tried to be. An in-depth analysis of Batman, but while that movie went off the wall and also wanted to be a silly comic book movie, this animated feature manages to keep a consistent tone and takes itself seriously. Almost like a Greek tragedy. I won't spoil much since this is an underrated movie and not many people have seen it. I suggest you watch it, I won't spoil the ending or the identity of the phantasm, you'll just have to watch it yourself. The only gripe I could have about this movie is that by the end of the movie the police haven't exactly cleared Batman, so he is technically still a fugitive, yet the signal lights up in the sky. It's a powerful ending, but that's just a small criticism in a near perfect movie.(9.8/10)

Batman, obviously, is not guilty, he is spotted at the scene moments after a mysterious figure vacates. What makes Phantasm so important is the human struggle of Bruce Wayne, as we see him go through heartbreak in various flashbacks, as he is forced to confront his troubled past when it threatens his wellbeing and stature in the present. Another interesting development is Mark Hamill's Joker, sidelined to a bit part although still crucial to the story. Nolan's Dark Knight put the Joker front and centre, grinding Batman almost into the ground; but Phantasm leaves the Joker as an irritant in Batman's side, and focuses on Wayne's personal troubles. It makes for an interesting and effective story, and one that if we'd gone without, we almost certainly wouldn't have seen Nolan's trilogy in the same form as it is.

This is the Batman that I wish we were getting on the big screen right now. I just love how he genuinely acts as a detective piecing together clues, and he flat out refuses to kill people. He also didn't have an artificial Batman voice that sounded like someone who had just finished gargling gravel, thanks to the superb work by Kevin Conroy. In fact, the voice work throughout the film was second to none, particularly Conroy as Bruce/Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker. I also couldn't get enough of the score. Composer Shirley Walker did some remarkable things with the music and helped to intensify the atmosphere and also amp up the excitement of action scenes. I never watched the animated series (I haven't watched that many cartoons since I was a child) but the look of the film was solid. At times it seems a little too goofy, considering how dark they are trying to set the tone, but I think it gels fairly well.

Zack Snyder could have taken a lesson from Mask of the Phantasm to learn how to remind the audience of the death of the Waynes and what that means to Bruce. With nothing more than a picture on the wall and a visit to the grave we 100% understand without needing to see pearls falling to the ground again. However, the story-telling in Mask of the Phantasm wasn't always that solid and concise. I had some significant problems with the way the movie constantly jumped back-and-forth in time. If they were thinking about it more, they would have included a simple visual cue that would clue us into whether we were watching the past or the present. It's not a good sign when you have a film-viewer like myself being tempted to pause at the beginning of each new scene in order to figure out where we were in the timeline. The twist at the end is easy for most people to guess, but I didn't mind all that much because they cast suspicion on enough people that the reveal could have been different, so it was still a solid mystery.

There is a romance plot in the film which was necessary to the story, but I wasn't really convinced of their affection for one another. I think that stems from the fact that the movie skipped over some of the courtship moments in their relationship and just expected the audience to accept that the love was there. I was surprised that the movie left things relatively open and unresolved at the end, but I assume that was intended so that the story could fold back into the animated series. One opportunity that I feel like they missed was the chance to have Batman in a position where he's forced to defend the Joker. Because of his vow not to kill (or let people die) they had the chance to create a much stronger moment by putting the Joker's life on the line instead of Andrea. If Batman was given no alternative than to save his arch nemesis it would be marvelous. That's not to say the movie was bad for not doing what I wanted, I just saw the squandered potential for greatness. The film was a gem, though. It is definitely well-made and I'd say it's better than at least 3 live action movies starring Batman.

Batman: Mask of the Phantasm is directed by Eric Radomski and Bruce Timm who were the creators of Batman: The Animated Series, and it stars Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Dana Delany in an animated superhero film about Batman doing his usual stuff, until his ex-girlfriend comes back to Gotham, and 2 weeks before she was there, a new villain named Phantasm starts killing gang members, leaving people to believe that it was Batman that did it as they both look a little similar. When I first heard of it, it was from a YouTube video where the Joker has his well known laugh, and ever since then, I wanted to watch the movie, but however, it wasn't in a rental store nor the city library. So I got impatient and just buy it on Amazon, and got it about a week later. For their first film that's part of the animated series, I really enjoyed it. The voice acting is fantastic as I really believed that Kevin Conroy is really Batman, and Mark Hamill is Joker. The animation is really impressive as it  was just about all of it were hand drawn, and I'm glad they stuck with it as it could've been easier to do it all in computer animation. The story doesn't feel like an extended episode, and you actually don't need to watch the show in order to understand the film as it gives enough information about Batman/Bruce Wayne, and the old villain from the animated series like the Joker. The writing by Alan Burnett, Paul Dini, Martin Pasko, and Michael Reaves is great that it shown something that none of the live-action Batman films haven't done, are what Bruce Wayne's life is like before he became Batman, and actually seeing him do some detective work as none of the film's focused on his actual persona that's similar to the comics. It gives some laughs when it doesn't take it serious from the Joker, but when it gets serious, it does, and it gets suspenseful at times while also giving some fun fights. The only small problem about the film is that even though the kids are going to be shocked on the twist reveal, but for adults, it seem a little obvious on it, which I picked up on it too, even though it's not a bad twist, it's just not a shocking one. While it may not be as entertaining as The Dark Knight Trilogy or Tim Burton's Batman films, I can say that Batman: Mask of the Phantasm is the closest film that we got that shows what Batman actually is like.

Who ever thought an animated superhero movie was a good idea? Probably not that many people in the'90s, as they were already used to all the live action comic book adaptations they had been receiving for years. Additionally, the film's marketing campaign did not consist of all that much advertising at all, causing it to fly under the radar and perform underwhelmingly at the box office.

But more and more people are discovering this movie every passing year, and they're finding that, well, it's a really good Batman film. It has its flaws, for sure, but I can guarantee that the majority of Batman fans and non-fans alike will be able to find something in Mask of the Phantasm.

One minor negative I had with this film is a certain lack of emotional stakes. Personally, I simply often find it hard to take action seriously in cartoon movies, as it is seldom done very well. For me, Phantasm at times worked in this aspect, and other times didn't deliver the thrills I wanted it to.

However, that's just my opinion. And generally speaking, it doesn't bother me that much, because the story and the characters are so perfectly crafted in this film that you can't help but feel the same feeling that 1989's Batman and 2008's The Dark Knight left you with.

And is it as good as The Dark Knight? No, because that movie is pretty much the perfect superhero movie. But is it as terrible as Batman & Robin? Of course not. However, I do think it's the best animated Batman movie, and I'd also say it's even better than both Batman Returns and Batman Forever. Batman: Mask of the Phantasm is a clever, innovative animated film that I had a lot of fun with. Though it can't really match the intensity of some slightly superior Batman movies, Phantasm is sure to entertain audiences everywhere, and marks a solid entry in the DC Comics canon.

This is Batman: The Animated Series at its absolute best. Higher production values were put to good use as the movie's animation is sharp, while featuring more detailing in its art design as well as a more vivid color palette, without of course taking away from the noire aesthetic.

The plot surrounds the mystery behind the Phantasm, rooted by a look at the origins of Batman, and by extension Bruce Wayne's early adulthood. It also makes for a tragic love story, thus establishing Bruce's unwillingness to commit to a relationship. And, unlike the Animated series, it isn't afraid to portray more violent imagery, along with the death of human characters, one in particular getting an absolutely shocking reveal.

Speaking of which, the operatic music that couples the soundtrack also adds to the horror surrounding Phantasm and the film's noire aesthetic altogether. It is nothing short of stellar. The voice acting also holds up.

My only complaint is that it ends on a cliffhanger that is solved off-screen, while its drama comes off as a bit schmaltzy, although all this could be due to the running time falling short; a necessary trade-off for focusing on the film's overall quality.

That said, Mask of the Phantasm is a must-see Batman movie. Along with what was said prior, the suspense and action are bumped up a notch for constant thrills, even during its bits of origin exposition. And while I'm not familiar with the source material, and besides loving the Tim Burton live-action Batman films, Mask of the Phantasm probably is as close to the source material as it gets.
